{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3555858,"name":"AdrianBS","username":"Adrii","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adrii/{size}/213295_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T04:15:10.143Z","cooked":"

Hi, teams, I’m looking for help in calibrating the Swerve modules, and I wish you could help me with this.

I’m using Swerve Mk4i with CANCoders and SparkMax, and I’m having problems with calibrating the modules. When I calibrate them, after I turn the robot off and turn it back on they decalibrate and I have to re-align the wheels and do a Zero CANCoder. I am also using the YAGSL library to program the modules and everything related. I’m new to all this, this is our first season using Swerve, as well as our first season using Java. I don’t know how to leave a fixed calibration to the modules, and I wanted to know if you could help me. Thanks in advance.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-13T04:15:10.143Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":69,"readers_count":68,"score":48.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495411,"topic_slug":"swerve-decalibration-cancoder-sparkmax-yagsl","display_username":"AdrianBS","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63811,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-decalibration-cancoder-sparkmax-yagsl/495411/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555887,"name":"Dylan Powers","username":"Dylan1259","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dylan1259/{size}/161876_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T05:04:30.652Z","cooked":"

When you say “do a Zero CANCoder”, what exactly are you doing?

According to the YAGSL documentation, The calibration is stored in the JSON configuration file which is loaded upon robot start, are you putting your angle offsets into that JSON file using the tuning webpage on this page?

If you are ever having issues with YAGSL, try these 8 steps.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-13T05:04:30.652Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":63,"readers_count":62,"score":17.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495411,"topic_slug":"swerve-decalibration-cancoder-sparkmax-yagsl","display_username":"Dylan Powers","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.yagsl.com/configuring-yagsl/the-eight-steps","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"The eight steps | YAGSL","clicks":2},{"url":"https://docs.yagsl.com/configuring-yagsl/configuration","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Configuration | YAGSL","clicks":2},{"url":"https://docs.yagsl.com/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Welcome to Yet Another Swerve Document | YAGSL","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":42126,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-decalibration-cancoder-sparkmax-yagsl/495411/2","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3557406,"name":"AdrianBS","username":"Adrii","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adrii/{size}/213295_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-15T01:20:49.263Z","cooked":"

As we’re using CANCoders as Encoders of the modules, in the Phoenix Tuner X configuration there is the Zero CANCoder function, which gives the CANCoder the 0 point, which is supposed to calibrate it to a 0 point and in the YAGSL programming we only check the Offset angles.
What happens is that after some use, the angles of the CANCoders get decalibrated, and then they start to go less and less straight, and we have to recalibrate them and adjust that Angle Offset in the YAGSL JSON.

And an apology, if something is not understood, I’m not an English speaker.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-15T01:20:49.263Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":32,"readers_count":31,"score":11.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495411,"topic_slug":"swerve-decalibration-cancoder-sparkmax-yagsl","display_username":"AdrianBS","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":42126,"username":"Dylan1259","name":"Dylan Powers","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dylan1259/{size}/161876_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63811,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-decalibration-cancoder-sparkmax-yagsl/495411/3","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3557543,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-15T09:54:08.154Z","cooked":"

When you say “after some use”, that makes me wonder if the magnets are not permanently attached with retaining compound.

When you say “power off and back on”, that makes me think you’re not putting the offsets in the code.

For the second: don’t use the Phoenix zero function, but instead set that as if each CANcoder came right out of the box, then measure the offset with one of the dashboards and enter the offset into the frontleft.json etc files.

For the first issue, the magnets need to be permanently fixed in place and that’s often overlooked by first-time assemblers. We use Loctite 609.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-15T09:54:08.154Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":18,"readers_count":17,"score":8.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495411,"topic_slug":"swerve-decalibration-cancoder-sparkmax-yagsl","display_username":"Jim Sokoloff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":63811,"username":"Adrii","name":"AdrianBS","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adrii/{size}/213295_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"97 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-decalibration-cancoder-sparkmax-yagsl/495411/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558122,"name":"AdrianBS","username":"Adrii","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adrii/{size}/213295_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T04:04:09.612Z","cooked":"

We were looking for tutorials and videos, and we did glue the magnets to the structure, so they should not suffer from vibrations or other things like that.
We also added the Angle Offset to the code, so we have to calibrate them and then change it in the JSON of the modules, with the Angle Offset that the Shuffleboard gives us, so we are not sure what could be the cause of the decalibration.
We have been reviewing tutorials and also the YAGSL documentation, but we are not sure.
